note.body:
Is the idea that the shortcuts should match the physical (the primary) keyboard layout on your keyboard and shouldn't change when switching layouts?

If so I think the failure in expectation is that I use a laptop with a secondary keyboard attached which is actually what I use primarily for typing. So the shortcuts that I experience have very little relation to my keyboard.

Actually proper handling of secondary keyboard would be a nice to have feature.

If this is 5 `gtk+` related then that would explain a couple of other keyboard shortcut issues I had noticed. 

FYI:

keyboard layouts are: `German` and `English (US)`

Thanks for your answer and your great work. Lollypop is the best music player I used by now. Simple, clear and efficient without too much things (like iTunes I was using when I was on Apple Mac).

events.target_title: Unable to Remove NVIDIA Driver on GNOME Software

note.body:
Output of the related command is empty.
>  Could you rephrase? I unfortunately don't understand what that comment means.

Of course I'll explain with detail: I have installed KDE Software Center that software's name is "Discover" because I wanted to expose that is GNOME Software Center problem or not. I checked installed applications that related to NVIDIA via Discover and there's nothing about it. Lastly, I checked "installable over internet" applications by searching "NVIDIA" and there's an package "NVIDIA Linux Graphics Driver" that is installable with Discover but not with GNOME Software Center. There's an picture that explains what I mean: ![nvidia2](/uploads/157a6789016ad970b380b4e1cfedf6d4/nvidia2.png)

Edit: I solved halfly with following steps: Activate NVIDIA RPMFusion repository, Kill gnome-software, Open gnome-software. But I deactivate that repository, the problem appears again.

events.target_title: Fractional Scaling results in blur

note.body: Because of that issue, I'm staying with Windows. I love GNOME and can't stand with other DEs but GNOME Wayland is cannot usable because of the that issue. And forcing all developers to use native Wayland or nothing approach is not realistic either, you should provide good back compatibility support up to a developer decides their program work native Wayland and any user shouldn't feel much difference. I'm OK with little blurness but not that much. Scaling 1440x900 to 2160x1440 (for me) produces unusable environment. If you come to me with the idea of the Windows' legacy thing and if you say that they are also blurring old apps, I'll say that old apps on Windows looks so much better than fractional-scaled Xwayland apps on GNOME. If someone will take action for that issue, I'll definitely going to start to use GNOME Wayland, finally. I really really want to use GNOME Wayland. I also tried changing the resolution Xwayland 1440x900 to native, but cannot access the server. That's why I cannot use GNU/Linux.

events.target_title: load stations from another thread
Offer "Sleep" (or "Power save") as the fourth option in the power down dialog from the system menu

note.body:
I think we should consider separating everything in different popovers, instead of having one giant popover/bar. For example, the wifi popover should be visible after pressing the wifi icon in the panel. Every icon in the panel should have a popover with the corresponding menu.
This is what the elementary os team is doing.
Then we could have a shutdown icon, with a corresponding popover containing all the actions (shutdown, suspend, hibernate, exit session)

events.target_title: The Lock signal is not emitted by systemd-logind when the screen is locked

note.body:
Personally I need to intercept this event to switch keyboard to EN before lock screen / going to sleep. Sleep event can be intercepted via `dbus-monitor`, but for lock screen I had to redefine `Super+L` shortcut with custom script:

```sh
# switch to en
gdbus call --session --dest org.gnome.Shell --object-path /org/gnome/Shell --method org.gnome.Shell.Eval "imports.ui.status.keyboard.getInputSourceManager().inputSources[0].activate()"

# lock screen
dbus-send --type=method_call --dest=org.gnome.ScreenSaver /org/gnome/ScreenSaver org.gnome.ScreenSaver.Lock
```

events.target_title: -d device option not working

note.body:
I have code to fix this, if the team is interested in accepting it. I'm also running into this issue.

Cheese seems to walk all possible devices. Sometimes it gets the one you want, sometimes it doesn't. No preference is given to the -d option. What my change does is keep the current behavior in the absence of -d, but when -d is provided, that node (and *ONLY* that node) is used. If the node doesn't exist, or is broken, cheese will exit rather than selecting another camera. Ought I make a PR?

note.body: If so, please assign me the bug, and I'll get it out for review ASAP.

events.target_title: Eyedrop tool doesn't work when screen composing (KWin) is enabled.

note.body:
Can confirm that (tested from Plasma 5.12 to Plasma 5.15)  

It happens with default KWin configuration. Specifically when you have:  
a) Enabled effect "Color Picker" (hidden under 'Internal Desktop Effects')   
b) Compositor backend is "OpenGl 2" or "OpenGL 3"  

If I switch backend to XRender OR disable that effect OR set rule to block compositing for GIMP, Eyedropper works fine.  
Also worth noting that Flatpak version is not affected (yet?)

----
I opened bug at [KDE Bugtracking](https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=407226) and KWin developer Vlad Zagorodniy spotted such warning

`(gimp:23528): GLib-CRITICAL **: 12:00:48.423: the GVariant format string '(u)' has a type of '(u)' but the given value has a type of '((u))'`  

>  It means that GIMP can't unpack color information sent by KWin.  

KWin developers think that it's probably GIMP's issue.  

Also it's kinda regression because previous major version 2.8.12 works properly.

events.target_title: Mutter master crashing. Black screen on startup.

note.body:
You say you tried to run master version of mutter. What shell version do you run? Some big refactorings landed recently (MR420), so in order to use latest mutter you have to compile and install it, then compile latest gnome-shell against it. Maybe some other projects are affected as well.

Search through journalctl output, if you see something like "symbol lookup failed" for  "meta_x11_display_focus_the_no_focus_window", that is exactly the case

events.target_title: Mutter master crashing. Black screen on startup.

note.body:
Unfortunately master version of mutter is incompatible with stable gnome-shell due to API changes, so you'll have to go all the way. Latest tagged version (3.33.2) is compatible tho, so if you can apply patches to it, you can go for it.

I've ran into the same problem when i tried to test out some nvidia related MR. Since then i've decided to wait until next point release gets tagged and pushed into Fedora Rawhide.

Regarding GDM and why it is affected: the way things stand, gnome-shell is a mutter plugin, it uses mutter APIs. GDM (post gnome3) is kind of gnome-shell plugin or a modified gnome-shell session (you can see second gnome-shell instance running, when you run gnome-shell with GDM).

events.target_title: Mutter master crashing. Black screen on startup.

note.body:
Mutter 3.33.2 should still work with gnome-shell 3.32.x

Looking at the spec in rawhide, to build gnome-shell 3.33.x, newer version of evolution-data-server (>= 3.33.1) is required.

Also i remember i had to switch off sysprof option in meson.options to build mutter, otherwise i could not build it in Fedora.

events.target_title: Moving the mouse while alt-tabbing is chaos!

note.body:
FWIW, the second option is close to how Windows (W10 specifically, but probably older versions as well) implements it:
*  Mouse and keyboard have different indicators (mouse highlight is thin inner border, keyboard select is thick outer border) (as Barrel0Luck proposed)
*  Mouse cursor only highlights windows, you have to click to actually select

I realize people sometimes look at MS UX solutions with contempt, but it might pass as a known solution and a familiar one at that (for people who migrate), so it might hold some merit

events.target_title: Allow to disable the "App not responding" dialog feature

note.body:
I had a feeling that "State: t (tracing stop)" might not be a convention that is followed by everyone. So i went and tested debuggers in various IDE's for various languages, namely:
*  .NET (VS Code)
*  Java (IntelliJ Idea)
*  Python (IntelliJ Pycharm)
*  C (qtcreator)

Among listed cases, only C debug sessions produced "t (tracing stop)" state at a breakpoint. All of the rest are stopping with state "S (sleeping") which makes me think proposed solution won't work for managed platforms/interpreters.

Have to note, that only GUI apps seem to be affected, console apps/backend services that do not produce actual windows can be debugged indefinitely (which is kinda obvious)

events.target_title: Separate workspaces on multiple monitors

note.body:
It would be a great improvement, however:

1) Under X it is known to be a violation of EWMH. Tiling WM's do it anyway, but you have to be careful with implementation, as it caused problems in the past: https://github.com/awesomeWM/awesome/issues/170

2) Not sure where Wayland stands on this. Do they ever have something like EWMH?

events.target_title: New GHashTable implementation confuses valgrind

note.body:
Here's a pretty simple testcase to show the problem:

```
#include <glib.h>

int
main (void)
{
  static GHashTable *table;

  table = g_hash_table_new_full (g_str_hash, g_str_equal, g_free, g_free);
  g_hash_table_insert (table, g_strdup ("key"), g_strdup ("value"));

  return 0;
}
```

Which shows something like:

```
==14485== HEAP SUMMARY:
==14485==     in use at exit: 18,766 bytes in 12 blocks
==14485==   total heap usage: 12 allocs, 0 frees, 18,766 bytes allocated
==14485== 
==14485== 4 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 2 of 12
==14485==    at 0x483874F: malloc (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-amd64-linux.so)
==14485==    by 0x48A35D0: g_malloc (gmem.c:99)
==14485==    by 0x48BD2CE: g_strdup (gstrfuncs.c:363)
==14485==    by 0x1091AC: main (in /home/desrt/code/cockpit/r)
==14485== 
==14485== 6 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 3 of 12
==14485==    at 0x483874F: malloc (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-amd64-linux.so)
==14485==    by 0x48A35D0: g_malloc (gmem.c:99)
==14485==    by 0x48BD2CE: g_strdup (gstrfuncs.c:363)
==14485==    by 0x10919D: main (in /home/desrt/code/cockpit/r)
==14485== 
==14485== LEAK SUMMARY:
==14485==    definitely lost: 10 bytes in 2 blocks
==14485==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==14485==      possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==14485==    still reachable: 18,756 bytes in 10 blocks
==14485==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==14485== Reachable blocks (those to which a pointer was found) are not shown.
==14485== To see them, rerun with: --leak-check=full --show-leak-kinds=all
==14485== 
==14485== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v
==14485== ERROR SUMMARY: 2 errors from 2 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
```

In short: valgrind correctly notices that the hashtable is reachable (from the static), but fails to find the strings stored inside of it.  Note the small (<32bit) pointer values.  Running valgrind with `--aspace-minaddr=0x100000000` fixes it.

Note: there's no actual leak here.  Just valgrind getting confused.

note.body:
When I attempt to install 'Applications Menu' on Ubuntu 19.04, the result is an error and I get this on syslog:

gnome-shell[1803]: Extension "apps-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com" had error: TypeError: this._onCapturedEvent is undefined

events.target_title: xmlRegexpExec fails to match a Regular Expression on Latest libxml2 [2.9.9]

note.body: There are subtle differences regarding the regular expression syntax. In XML Schema, "the regular expression language defined here implicitly anchors all regular expressions at the head and tail" (see https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#dt-regex). Therefore, you should not use ^ or $ within your pattern. Just leave these out and then your pattern should accept empty strings.

events.target_title: Regular expression with an empty branch at the end is not considered valid
xmlRegexpExec fails to match a Regular Expression on Latest libxml2 [2.9.9]

note.body:
Correct. Now the pattern in the schema is valid, but libxml2 does not like it. I noticed this shortly after my comment to your issue, and entered a new issue for that, #57.

There is a work-around that I tried that seems to work: enclose everything in round brackets and add a question mark (zero or one occurrances). This allows the empty string also, end does not need the empty alternative.

In your case, that would be `"([0-9a-fA-F]{6})?"`

events.target_title: gnome-shell 3.30.2 freezes for a while when >=7 keys pressed repeatedly using a N-Key Rollover keyboard.

note.body:
A couple of followups to my previous post:

1. This only occurs in gnome-shell, not in LXDE or i3 (or, looking at the plover list, Unity).

2. `imbus` is set in gnome-shell:

   ~~~
   $ env | grep XMODIFIERS
   XMODIFIERS=@im=ibus
   ~~~

   It is not set in LXDE. *However*, unsetting it (`export XMODIFIERS=""` or `unset`) doesn't seem to change anything. The input still buffers until I stop typing.

3. This is all on X11 (plover can't modify the keypresses for wayland)

note.body:
The above workaround is still necessary in Ubuntu 19.04. For the new default Yaru icon theme it needs to be adapted to something like this:

```
sudo ln -sr /usr/share/icons/Yaru/scalable/actions/mark-location-symbolic.svg /usr/share/icons/Yaru/scalable/actions/mark-location.svg
sudo gtk-update-icon-cache -f /usr/share/icons/Yaru
```

Thanks to this bug report I can now actually *use* Gnome Maps, and I'm starting to really like it. Of course a fix would be even better than a workaround ...

@mlundblad, as per your suggestions I:

1) removed the aliased icon in the Yaru theme folder, updated its cache, restarted Gnome Maps. Result as expected: the bug was back.

2) saved a copy of your icon to the suggested location, restarted Gnome Maps. Result again as expected: bug gone, search working.

So bundling a mark-location icon with Maps is certainly a good idea, considering its importance for the app's functionality.

events.target_title: New Image Scaling Dialog Defaults to "pixels/mm"

note.body:
Interesting. Having to learn a LOT more about PNG files than I know previously. Thanks for interesting pointers. Here are my current observations:
1) The base PNG specification only includes "unknown" and "meters" as per the code. See: https://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110/#13Pixel-dimensions
2) Windows paint stores files using only the limited original PNG meters units. No EXIF.
3) Windows snipping tool also stores files only using the original PNG meter units. No EXIF.
4) GIMP 2.8.22 does not have nearly as many export options, does not have a "Save EXIF data" option and exports only the original PNG options (no EXIF options).
5) GIMP 2.8.22 - EXIF ignorance notwithstanding - shows me "pixels/in" as the default when I ask to scale an image. This is extremely handy because I am working with the U.S. publishing industry that thinks in DPI, not in pixels/m or pixels/mm.
6) If I scale the image to 300.00 pixels/in in GIMP 2.8.22 and then export it or overwrite the previous image, GIMP 2.8.22 saves the pixels/m data - just like Windows Paint and Windows Snipping Tool and my publishing chain tools. Everyone is happy.
7) GIMP 2.10.10 - Now has many more export options and indeed saves the EXIF options in addition to the PNG options...
8) But this really doesn't do anything for me one way or the other. The rest of the publishing toolchain is out of my control and may or may not pay attention to the EXIF data...
9) In the end, my problem is not how the data is stored - unfortunately, I have to assume that the rest of the toolchain will ignore EXIF and only look at the original somewhat stupid PNG "pixels per meter" fields. It is critical that those are stored properly. EXIF extras don't bother me, but probably don't do anything useful for me anyway....
10) Rather, my need is in the user interface. GIMP 2.8.22 came up by default with the unit I need to work with: "pixels/in" - even if the real data in the file was "pixels/m".  GIMP 2.10.10 now comes up with a new unit "pixels/mm" which is not what is in the file (which is pixels/m) and isn't what I use either (pixels/in).  Yes, I can pull down the menu each time and change to "pixels/in" but that is tedious when processing hundreds of files. What I would like is a preferences option to have GIMP assume that I want to work in "pixels/in" from the start...
(?)

Thanks,

David Hetherington

note.body:
Elle,
The png_get_pixels_per_inch()  function seems to be a convenience function.  If we look at the underlying PNG file format specification, it looks like the original PNG file format has only two units: "unknown" and "meters". 
See "11.3.5.3 pHYs Physical pixel dimensions"  at:
https://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110/

What seems to be going on is that everyone saves the resolution in "pixels per meter" and then converts back and forth to whatever the users of their application need.  That is why exiftool yields output like this:
Pixels Per Unit X           : 11811Pixels Per Unit Y           : 11811Pixel Units                     : meters
300 * (1000/2.54) = 118,110.236
David Hetherington

events.target_title: Improve translation workflow by using Weblate or something similar

note.body: @haecker-felix I would perhaps correct my original statement, Damned Lies is more of mailing list than anything else. It would be nice if Shortwave streamlined the translation workflow by using [Weblate](https://weblate.org/) (which should provide free online string hosting given the FOSS nature of this app, although you can always self-host). Enjoying the first beta thus far. :smile:

events.target_title: Improve translation workflow by using Weblate or something similar

note.body:
Correct, I'm part of one and they are valuable resources for asking questions, etc. However I think one of the issues in localizing the GNOME project (and KDE/Plasma for that matter) is the barrier to entry both technical (e.g. learning SVN/Git, find and download a localization tool for their OS) and semi-autonomy.

With a tool like Weblate, a user creates an account, selects a non-translated string, types the localization, and hits 'Suggest' (where it can either then be approved by designated language editor(s) or go in without any holds). Dead simple for translation contributors as they don't need to know anywhere as much computer science nor have to deal with boilerplate stuff by signing a commit, etc every change. If we in the FOSS community want to make localization better, we need to make it much less intimidating and more easy to contribute. Organized mailing lists while a useful resource do not streamline localization contributions the way tools like Weblate do.

note.body:
Thanks Milan. I have taken a look through the RFC and the flowed text option is what I am trying to achieve when replying to either HTML or plain text messages.

events.target_title: Text not wrapped when replying to iPhone ot Mac emails in HTML format.

note.body:
Hi Milan

Thanks for the suggestion which I have tried but with no benefit. To be clear I have tried all of these options:

Reply Style: Inline
Reply Style: Quoted
Wrap quoted text in replies: Enabled
Wrap quoted text in replies: Disabled

THe only change the 'Wrap quoted text' option makes it seems is to place a vertical blue line onto the right-hand edge of the email editor which doesn't seem to have any effect. 

Perhaps to make the problem even simpler, here's another example:

1. Receive a plain text email from any source (I actually got one this morning with my mobile phone bill attached!). Evolution correctly wraps the lines of this in the preview window. Perfect.
2. Forward this to myself using HTML format. Now the lines of the original email are all running off the right-hand end of the page (i.e. are no longer wrapped by Evolution).

The same also happens if I 'reply' the email to myself too. It seems to me that when the plain text email is converted to HTML, it is assigned the 'Preformatted' style. If I manually highlight the quoted text and change it to 'Normal' then it is correctly wrapped. Is this something which can either set as an option in Evolution or the default changed to avoid what must be a very common issue?

Thanks
Nick

events.target_title: Message list facelift

note.body:
Surely there is a concept of a single subject that defines a whole conversation, since the the listing of messages in a folder on the left (or center) already has this.

I think many email clients (I just checked gmail) don't repeat the subject line per message. Perhaps if a messages's subject line was different (except for the "Re: " prefix) then maybe display the subject as it currently does. But I think in most cases if the subject line is different then it indicates a new conversation - I've used this strategy in the past to force prevent gmail from grouping email together.

note.body:
The underlying issue is a gdk limitation, these warnings precede the segfault:

```

(evince:31227): Gdk-WARNING **: 10:59:29.833: Native Windows wider than 65535 pixels are not supported

(evince:31227): Gdk-CRITICAL **: 10:59:29.889: gdkdisplay-wayland.c:1402: Unable to create Cairo image surface: invalid value (typically too big) for the size of the input (surface, pattern, etc.)
```

But I think evince should handle this.

events.target_title: Ability to create Albums

note.body:
I am hope that "Albums" still being considered for a future feature of shotwell (bug 715270). I think "albums" is a wonderful idea and would be a welcome addition to photoshot. I don't see their absence as a "bug" but rather a missing useful feature.

In my experience (Picasa), albums can be a powerful tool for creating multiple slide-shows from a common set of images. For example:
- two albums could have some pictures in common but presented in different order.
- multiple albums might contain the same image but with different image processing (cropping, etc).
- a single album might contain the same image several times with different image processing (eq several different crops of the same image).
